data.author: Yinzhe Shen
data.message:
FindGeographicLib: Fix for GeographicLib 2.* and Windows

Since GeographicLib version 2, the library name changed from `libGeographic.so` to `libGeographicLib.so`, see https://github.com/geographiclib/geographiclib/blob/5e4425da84a46eb70e59656d71b4c99732a570ec/NEWS#L208 .
To ensure that GeographicLib 2.* is found correcty, I think we should add also `GeographicLib` to the names used by `find_library`.
Furthermore, on Windows the import library is called `GeographicLib-i.lib` (see https://github.com/geographiclib/geographiclib/blob/v2.3/src/CMakeLists.txt#L119), so to find the library correctly on Windows we also look for GeographicLib-i .

data.author: Fabian Poggenhans
data.message:
Create an own testing suite for mrt_cmake_modules

The suite can handle ctest (builds the source automatically).
Rostest, gtest and nosetest are supported similar to catkin (outputting xml results in the same dir).
Additionally, coverage results are generated and output to the command line, together with an url that can be opened in the browser. This works for both ctest and normal (catkin) builds.
If python-coverage is installed, python coverage is included as well.
Building with the toplevel cmakelists works as well.

data.author: Filipe Rinaldi
data.message:
Fix build for non-x86 architectures

When MRT_ARCH is not explicitly set, UseMrtStdCompilerFlags.cmake
currently forces the target architecture to be tuned to the Sandy Bridge
(x86) architecture.

This patch constraints this behaviour to x86-based targets. This allow
projects based on MRT Cmake Modules to be rebuild transparently in other
architectures without any extra build settings.

Note that this change works with both cross-compilation and native
non-x86 builds.

See #7.

Change-Id: Ibc1ed1eaf1c014df4c44d774ea8fd3760a1679e7
Signed-off-by: Filipe Rinaldi <filipe.rinaldi@arm.com>

data.author: Johannes Beck
data.message:
Improved CUDA support.

Beginning with cmake 3.9 the native CUDA language support in cmake is used to
build cuda files. This is achived by building a separate shared library for
the cuda files as this is the only way to select differnt GCC version, as the
current CUDA (10.2) version is not compatible with gcc 8.

The problem which arises which libraries needs to be linked into the cuda
shared library. Linking just all libraries does not work as some external
libraries like PCL carries flags in target_link_libraries which nvcc does
not understand. Using no library (like it is in the current approach) work
in many cases but not when e.g. OpenCV is used in CUDA code.

This MR adds a new flag to the <external> section in the package.xml
<cuda_depend> where one can specify the librarys which one would like
to link to CUDA code.

Also the behaviour when cuda code in executables is simplified (only
building a single shared library instead of an object file linked to a
shared library file).

data.message:
Improved Qt experience.

This PR makes it possbile to use the standard mrt cmake file for QT
projects. To achive that, the find script uses the targets insteads of
the libraries for QT_LIBRARIES because the targets also adds
compiler flags, etc. In addition, the source directory of executables
are added so that ui files referencing header files in the source
tree are working out of the box.

data.author: Johannes Beck
data.message:
Fix include order of boost python.

Due to the fact that the function mrt_add_python_api
searches for BoostPython and PythonLibs and adds those
to the include directories they are listed before the
project include folder. This leads to problems, if there is
a header in python which has the same name as in the project.
This patch resolves that issue by removing the find_package
handling and moving it auto depend.

Use standard CMake features to select C++ standard

This makes sure to use the right flags for every compiler.
It also makes sure that no other standard is selected later on by some
dependency.

data.author: Niels Ole Salscheider
data.message:
O3 is a bad idea, remove it

O3 is not guaranteed to speed things up. In fact, it often slows code down
because of the increased binary size. It should only be used on a
case-by-case basis after benchmarking.
